description: From Middle English overflowen, from Old English oferflōwan, equivalent to over- +‎ flow.

entries.meaning: The spillage resultant from overflow; excess.
Outlet for escape of excess material.
(computing) The situation where a value exceeds the available numeric range.

verbs.description: overflow (third-person singular simple present overflows, present participle overflowing, simple past overflowed, past participle overflowed or (US, proscribed) overflown)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To flow over the brim of (a container).
(transitive) To cover with a liquid, literally or figuratively.
examples: The flash flood overflowed most of the parkland and some homes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To flow over the edge of a container.
examples: The waters overflowed into the Ninth Ward.

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive, intransitive) To (cause to) exceed the available numeric range.
examples: Calculating 255+1 will overflow an eight-bit byte.
I see and feel that I want the first requisite — a heart overflowing with Divine love towards sinners
